item.title: Operator Overlading in Probability
item.description: Mulitple ways of interpreting summation operation. Fix input x, then everything on rhs becomes scalar Keep LHS a variable, then RHS are vectors/tables By correctly interpreting the conventions of the sum/product over factors, the two are identical. Assume all examples below uses discrete random variables with $K$ states. Marginalization and Sum: Fundamental Examples:

item.title: About Me
item.description: Hi, Iâ€™m Max Wasserman. I enjoy all forms of disciplined movement (weight lifting, gymnastics, yoga), meditation, and using engineering principles to build useful things. I grew up in suburban New Jersey, spent a few years in Philadelphia for undergrad, and now find myself in Rochester, NY for my PhD advised by Dr. Gonzalo Mateos. I currently work on projects attempting to extend machine learning tools such as Deep Neural Networks to graph structured data.
